report_title: Industry Report on Business Valuation Services
executive_summary: Revenue for business valuation firms has been volatile during the current period. The strong economy pre-pandemic boosted business confidence, so companies engaged in many mergers and acquisitions (M&As), aiding revenue growth. Halting economic activity during COVID-19 caused corporate profit to plunge in 2020. This gave companies far fewer funds to invest in business valuation services, resulting in falling revenue growth during the pandemic. As corporate profit and consumer spending soared during the pandemic recovery, revenue recovered. Spending from individuals proceeded to slow recently because of declining per capita disposable income. This slowed investment in the industry's services from households and individuals. Access to credit has increased recently, causing households and businesses to purchase more assets. They've increased their uptake in business valuation services to determine the value of these new assets.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Surging Confidence Caused Revenue to Soar Right Before the Pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The economy was strong at the beginning of the current period, as the United States was in the final stages of an expansion following the 2008 financial crisis. Businesses were extremely confident, so they engaged in mergers and acquisitions (M&As) at a rapid pace, boosting demand for business valuation services. Interest rates were also relatively low, making it easier for companies to borrow, which raised M&A activity and the purchase of stocks, bonds and financial derivatives. Many corporations sought to find the value of the business valuation services so they can find the value of the assets or companies they're seeking to purchase.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry Displayed Significant Volatility During COVID-19
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: As state and local governments shut down businesses during the pandemic, corporate profit plunged as many companies couldn't function. Since corporations use their profit to purchase business valuation services, they reduced their investment in the industry's services during the pandemic, causing revenue to fall in 2020. Despite these challenges, the industry avoided a steep decline in revenue in 2020 because some business valuation services were highly sought after. Since the US economy was performing terribly during the pandemic, some corporations experienced bankruptcy and liquidation. Shareholders and investors in these companies sought business valuation services to value the assets of companies going under, which rescued revenue growth somewhat.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Plunging Per Capita Disposable Income Halted Revenue Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: During COVID-19, incomes soared because of a surge in government subsidies, including stimulus checks and unemployment insurance. Public help cost the government trillions of dollars per year, so they pulled the plug on aid as the economy recovered. This caused per capita disposable income to plunge in 2022. Lower incomes reduced consumers' ability to afford homes, cars and other assets. Since households commonly pay business valuation firms to estimate the value of these assets, revenue declined as the purchase of homes and vehicles fell.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The Economic Recovery Will Provide a Necessary Lifeline for Business Valuation Companies
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Despite challenges related to inflation, recessionary fears and rising interest rates, GDP is expected to grow modestly during the outlook period. Strong economic growth will raise business sentiment and corporate profit, causing more companies to engage in mergers and acquisitions (M&As), stock purchases and cash flow analyses, which will boost demand for the industry's services. Per capita disposable income will also expand, increasing investment in valuation services from households as more consumers will seek to estimate the value of cars, boats, homes and other expensive assets they seek to purchase. Demand for company valuations will also rise as individuals will want to determine if a corporation is stable enough for them to put their excess cash in.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: THE AGING POPULATION WILL MAKE BUSINESS VALUATION MORE CRUCIAL
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the population ages, baby boomers approaching retirement will seek to maximize their retirement portfolios. They want to receive the highest return on their investments, so they'll search for the bonds, stocks and other instruments that are the most valuable. To find the best companies to invest in for retirement, older households increase their uptake in valuation services, aiding revenue growth. The baby boomer generation is the wealthiest in the United States. As more boomers die or set up trust funds for their children, some younger people will become wealthier. With this newfound wealth, younger investors will start new businesses and purchase financial instruments, increasing spending on the industry's services and contributing to higher revenue growth during the outlook period.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Competition from Substitutes Will Become More Significant
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Accountants will increasingly offer business valuation products and traditional tax preparation services, raising their prevalence as a substitute for the industry's services. New software (e.g., YCharts, Bloomberg Terminal, Grata, QuickBooks, Performance Pro, Culture Amp) will enable corporations to access information on asset prices and retrieve a company's financial information quickly and efficiently. The increased prevalence of substitutes will enable companies to perform the industry's services in-house or migrate to other customers (e.g., accounting firms), siphoning revenue from the industry. The adoption of better software in particular will pose a serious threat to business valuation firms, as many corporations and individuals simply want basic information on a company before buying stocks, bonds and other financial instruments. Since new software will increasingly enable customers to do just that, they'll stop using traditional valuation companies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Innovations Will Seek to Keep the Industry Relevant
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While financial software such as YCharts and QuickBooks can be used by companies and individuals to replace the industry's services, business valuation firms will use big data to provide updated information on companies and various assets to their clients in an efficient and informed manner. They will seek to use new technology to keep their services relevant. Companies will also employ new financial models (e.g., risk-adjusted discount rates) to provide more specific information on cash flow to companies. Business valuation firms hope these innovations will keep their services attractive so clients don't produce them in-house or migrate to other industries.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry estimate the value of an owner's interest in a business. Business valuation firms determine how much an entity is willing to pay to buy a business or receive to sell a business. Business valuation can also be used for other legal and business purposes.
key_trends: Revenue has been volatile during the current period. High business confidence boosted downstream demand in the years right before the pandemic, while plunging corporate profit caused revenue to drop significantly during the pandemic.

The industry will face positive and negative headwinds during the outlook period. Steadily rising incomes will boost revenue growth through higher corporate profit, but competition from substitutes will significantly threaten business valuation firms' performance.
Business valuation firms must know the plethora of regulations governing financial institutions. Companies can also gain certifications to increase their notoriety.

The industry receives some assistance from public and private sources. Private organizations that boost business valuation firms include the American Society of Appraisers (ASA) and the National Association of Certified Valuators and Analysts (NACVA).

Spending on capitalization of income valuation has fallen during the current period. Demand for capitalization of income valuation depends on the level of mergers and acquisitions (M&As), which has plunged amid concerns related to inflation and recessionary fears.
Business valuation firms receive most of their revenue from private firms. Businesses' revenue share has expanded during the current period as corporate profit surged amid the pandemic recovery.

The Mid-Atlantic region is home to New York, the heart of the nation's financial industry. Since finance companies often invest and engage in mergers and acquisitions (M&As), demand for business valuation services is high in the Mid-Atlantic.

The Southeast region contains the largest share of the nation's population. The high population means that there are many businesses and individuals that use business valuation services, so the industry has a notable presence in the Southeast.

The physical capital needed to set up a business valuation firm is very low, as it often only requires a small office space and a computer. Low physical capital costs reduce barriers to entry, which hinders consolidation.
Business valuation firms compete with each other based on price, knowledge and reputation. They also compete with accountants, investment banks and business valuation software externally.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Private firms are the most significant market segment for business valuation firms, generating more than half of the industry's revenue. Companies that use business valuation services include retailers, raw materials producers, financial institutions, energy companies and manufacturers.

Individuals and households seek business valuation services when they want to invest in real estate and other types of assets. They ask companies to give them detailed information about the companies they're putting their money in. While the economy performed well during the pandemic recovery, per capita disposable income has fallen recently because of the expiration of COVID-19 relief, causing individuals' and households' revenue share to creep downward during the current period.

The public sector uses valuation services for litigation disputes, departmental mergers and evaluating assets and inventory. More public spending encourages agencies to analyze their balance sheets more meticulously, so investment in business valuation services from the public sector rises when government spending increases. Government spending rose in 2020 because Congress responded to the economic fallout related to COVID-19, but investment has crept downward recently as public officials have become more worried about deficits. Overall, public spending has been fairly flat during the current period, causing government agencies' revenue share to hold steady.

Not-for-profit organizations use business valuation services to determine what assets they should invest in. Nonprofit groups represent only a handful of the industry's customers, so they make up a comparatively small share of revenue.

products_and_services.product_description: Asset valuation is used to measure the value of a corporation's tangible assets. It's mostly performed on companies with lots of physical equipment and materials, such as retailers and manufacturers.

Capitalization of income valuation measures intangible assets and is often used for service-based firms. This form of valuation measures the degree of risk a company undergoes, profitability, location, competition, barriers to entry, technology, goodwill, customer base and other factors.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: DEMAND FOR CAPITALIZATION OF INCOME VALUATION IS DEPENDENT ON THE LEVEL OF MERGERS AND ACQUISITIONS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Capitalization of income valuation is often used by large corporations seeking to acquire another company, as they want to estimate the expected benefits after going through a merger and acquisition (M&A) deal. Concerns about inflation and recessionary fears have caused M&A activity to plunge recently, causing capitalization of income valuation's revenue share to decline during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: THE COVID-19 RECOVERY HAS BOOSTED SPENDING ON ASSET VALUATION
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As incomes and corporate profit have soared amid the pandemic recovery, more individuals and companies have paid business valuation firms to perform asset valuations on a corporation to determine if they should purchase their stock or lend money to them. As a result, asset valuation's revenue share has expanded during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: CONCERNS RELATED TO INFLATION HAVE MADE OWNER BENEFIT VALUATION MORE IMPORTANT
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Owner benefit valuation measures the discretionary cash flow of a business. Business valuation companies examine standard return on investment, debt service for the company and wages to estimate future cash flow. Since inflation has skyrocketed throughout the United States, individuals and corporations have spent more on owner-benefit valuations to more meticulously track the cash flow of the companies they're lending to or have ownership in, causing this segment's revenue share to rise during the current period.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: MARKET VALUATION SERVICES HAVE BECOME MORE POPULAR WITH BIG INVESTORS
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Market valuation measures a company's worth relative to its peers. Business valuation firms compare the company's worth to the average sales throughout the industry it operates in. As large investors have become more cautious in the face of recessionary fears, they've been demanding market valuation services to better understand what companies to invest in. As a result, this segment's revenue share to creep upward during the current period.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region, specifically the New York metropolitan area, contains many of the nation's major banks, private equity firms and financial institutions. Since these institutions engage in lots of mergers and acquisitions (M&As) and invest in many assets, demand for business valuation services is high, causing many establishments to locate in the Mid-Atlantic region.

The Southeast is home to big states such as Florida, Georgia, Tennessee and North Carolina, which makes the region populated. The high population ensures there's lots of activity among businesses, individuals and organizations. Naturally, some of these groups demand business valuation services, so the industry has a notable presence in this region.

The west region, specifically California, contains Silicon Valley, which is home to the nation's largest technology companies. These technology companies (e.g., Alphabet, Apple, Meta) often engage in M&As and invest in equities, bonds and other financial instruments when expanding their operations, so they demand business valuation services. This gives the industry a significant presence in the West region.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Companies must take into account federal tax, legal ownership, securities and accounting laws when valuing a business. Business valuation firms must specifically be concerned with changes in financial reporting guidelines. These guidelines are part of generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP), which are written by the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB). The actions of the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) also affect the industry because the body regulates stock exchanges, debt instruments, company annual reports and accounting rules.

The Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989 authorized the Appraisal Subcommittee (ASC) in Congress to provide oversight to the Appraisal Foundation, which is governed by eight large appraisal organizations. The foundation oversees the Appraisal Practices Board, Appraisal Standards Board and Appraiser Qualifications Board. Many of their rules pertain to real estate valuations and other forms of non-business assets.

Individuals can gain the Accredited Senior Appraiser designation of the American Society of Appraisers and the Certified Business Appraiser (CBA) designation of the Institute of Business Appraisers. They can also become a Certified Valuation Analyst (CVA) or an Accredited Valuation Analyst (AVA) from the National Association of Certified Valuation Analysts. None of these certifications are required to work in the industry, but they help business valuation firms gain credibility, which often brings in more customers.

barriers_points.barrier_description: These employees are paid well since they're highly skilled, making labor costs a significant barrier to entry.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Prevalence of nonemployers keeps industry fragmented
concentration_points.concentration_description: Individuals who have extensive knowledge of finance often set up their own business valuation firms and sell their services to businesses.

Nonemployers have proliferated because of localization. Individuals selling business valuation services have personal relationships with the households and businesses operating in their specific town, state or region, fostering loyalty.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Loyalty makes acquiring small firms difficult
concentration_points.concentration_description: The prevalence of loyalty has made it extremely difficult for large players to acquire small companies and nonemployers, reducing market share concentration.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Low capital requirements enable new entrants
concentration_points.concentration_description: The physical capital required to set up a business valuation firm is extremely modest, as players often only need a computer, some software, an office space, and a handful of subscriptions.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Contracts help large players gain share
concentration_points.concentration_description: While low start-up costs raise fragmentation, the prevalence of contracts helps large players. Prominent business valuation companies are more well-known, so they're more likely to enter into contracts with major corporations, which raises concentration somewhat.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: While revenue has increased significantly since the end of COVID-19, intense competition among small companies and nonemployers has forced companies to charge lower prices, limiting profit growth.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: EMPLOYEES HAVE BEEN DEMANDING HIGHER PAY AS PRICES RISE
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As inflation has picked up, these employees have been put under pressure by rising prices, causing them to ask for raises. Employers have mostly relented since their highly skilled workers can switch to other industries if they so choose. As a result, wages' revenue share has risen during the current period.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: PRICIER SUBSCRIPTIONS HAVEN'T AFFECTED PURCHASE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: As inflation has surged, information providers have been raising the cost of their subscriptions to stay in business. Despite rising subscription costs, purchases' revenue share has held pretty steady during the current period as many business valuation firms locked in subscription prices with their upstream suppliers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Miscellaneous Costs Have Been Crowded Out By Other Categories
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Inflation has significantly raised the cost of other categories, particularly wages. As a result, they've been eating into miscellaneous costs, causing their share of revenue to drop during the current period.

volatility_points.volatility_title: SHIFTS IN CORPORATE PROFIT FOSTER VOLATILITY
volatility_points.volatility_description: Corporate profit plunged during COVID-19 as companies couldn't operate effectively. This trend reversed itself during the pandemic recovery as consumers flocked to stores, restaurants and other businesses in droves. Overall, big fluctuations in corporate profit have enhanced revenue volatility during the current period.

volatility_points.volatility_title: INVESTOR UNCERTAINTY HAS CAUSED REVENUE TO FLUCTUATE
volatility_points.volatility_description: COVID-19, the pandemic recovery, inflation, rising interest rates and recessionary fears have caused economic conditions to be extremely volatile during the current period. This has raised investor uncertainty, which has boosted revenue volatility recently.

FAQs.question: Does your company face significant competition from substitute goods or services?
FAQs.answer: Some individuals and small businesses use business valuation software as a less expensive alternative to preliminary value studies.

FAQs.question: How have economic changes influenced consumer demand for your services?
FAQs.answer: Business valuation firms benefit from rising corporate profit and an improving investment environment resulting from more robust economic growth. The industry also benefits from counter-cyclical trends (i.e., business bankruptcies requiring litigation-based appraisals).

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in locations with well-established metropolitan areas?
FAQs.answer: The industry's largest operators tend to be located in major metropolitan cities to service a large number of businesses.

FAQs.question: To what degree are your operations capital intensive?
FAQs.answer: The industry has a low level of capital intensity since the business valuation is very service based.

FAQs.question: Business valuation activities are labor-intensive, and wages are the most significant expense in this industry.
FAQs.answer: Wages are the largest expense for industry operators, comprising nearly four-tenths of revenue in 2023.

FAQs.question: Has the implementation of new technology altered or disrupted your company's service offerings?
FAQs.answer: Business valuation software is a major threat to small industry operators.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to minimize/reduce wage costs through automation?
FAQs.answer: Wages are the largest expense for industry operators, comprising nearly four-tenths of revenue in 2023.

FAQs.question: What are the toughest regulatory requirements that your company experiences?
FAQs.answer: The Uniform Standards of Professional Appraisal Practice (USPAP) provides quality control to business valuation appraisal analysis and reports in the United States.

FAQs.question: Do you work with industry associations or other groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: The American Society of Appraisers (ASA) is an international organization of appraisal professionals. Associations support the profession through certification, lobbying and continuing education.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit margin compare with those of your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: The average profit margin for the industry is moderate.

FAQs.question: How has your company's profitability trended in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Profit has remained stable during the current period. Operators will shift toward specialized services for growing markets (e.g., healthcare) to boost profit.

FAQs.question: Do you have a strong reputation among customers? How can you improve your reputation?
FAQs.answer: A reputation for accuracy and reliability is advantageous in this industry, particularly as many firms are relatively small operators that lack extensive marketing capacity.

FAQs.question: How do you retain a highly skilled workforce?
FAQs.answer: Clients will engage a business valuation company based on its analysts having a high degree of knowledge concerning business valuations.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to?
FAQs.answer: Operators can be more successful if they have specialized skills or services and can serve a niche market.

FAQs.question: How can you cater to an increase in investor uncertainty?
FAQs.answer: Investor uncertainty represents the expected annualized change of the S&P 500 over the next 30 days.

FAQs.question: How did restricted access to credit affect your company during the recession?
FAQs.answer: Access to credit increases the ability of companies to invest in strategies to grow their business.

FAQs.question: How have changes in business activity affected your company's revenue?
FAQs.answer: Business valuation firms provide appraisals for companies that are entering bankruptcy.
